news-item.title: Miner killed after accident during maintenance job
news-item.author: Evansville Courier & Press. Richard Gootee, gooteer@courierpress.com, 812-464-7431
news-item.text: An underground coal miner died from injuries sustained while performing equipment maintenance early Tuesday morning at the Gibson County LLC mine near Princeton. The company identified the miner as Timothy W. Memmer, 41, of Princeton. According to a statement from the company, Memmer and another worker "were performing maintenance work on a piece of mining equipment underground when an unexpected movement of the equipment" injured Memmer. The incident happened at about 1:45 a.m. The other worker, who was not identified, was not hurt. The cause of the incident remains under investigation." "Our thoughts and prayers are with the Memmer family," the company's statement read. "Gibson County Coal asks that you join us in extending support to Mr. Memmer's family and his fellow Gibson miners during this extremely difficult time." The mine is located at 6880 W. County Road 200 North, which is near Princeton. Before Tuesday, there had no deaths at Hoosier coal mines in 2014. There was one death each in 2012 and 2013, according to the U.S. Department of Labor. The death in 2013 was at the Five Star Prosperity Mine in Petersburg, according to the Indiana Bureau of Mines. According to that bureau's 2013 annual report, the Gibson County LLC mine employs about 370 workers. It had 13 reported accidents in 2013, six of which caused employees to lose time.
